name: Distance Formula
statement: The distance between two points (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂) is √((x₂ - x₁)² + (y₂ - y₁)²).
philosophy: This formula defines Euclidean distance in 2D space using the Pythagorean theorem.

name: Midpoint Formula
statement: The midpoint of a segment between points (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂) is ((x₁ + x₂)/2, (y₁ + y₂)/2).
philosophy: Identifies the center of a segment, useful in symmetry and triangle centroid analysis.

name: Slope of a Line
statement: The slope m of a line through points (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂) is (y₂ - y₁) / (x₂ - x₁), x₁ ≠ x₂.
philosophy: Encodes the angle and direction of a line in Cartesian space.

name: Collinearity via Slope
statement: Three points are collinear if the slopes between each pair are equal.
philosophy: Collinearity is established when all segment directions align.

name: Slope Multiplication Rule for Perpendicularity
statement: Two lines are perpendicular if the product of their slopes is -1.
philosophy: Encodes orthogonality in linear relationships through negative reciprocal slopes.

name: Triangle Area by Coordinates
statement: The area of triangle with vertices (x₁, y₁), (x₂, y₂), (x₃, y₃) is ½ |x₁(y₂ - y₃) + x₂(y₃ - y₁) + x₃(y₁ - y₂)|.
formal: A = ½ |x₁(y₂ - y₃) + x₂(y₃ - y₁) + x₃(y₁ - y₂)|
philosophy: Efficient formula for triangle area directly from coordinates, useful for collinearity and ratio problems.
